title: Bank of America issued a 1099 for discharge of debt to me, but refuses to update credit report as it still shows outstanding?
question: BofA discharged the debt by sending me a 1099 for $30K back in 2012. However, I cannot purchase a house because they refuse to update the credit report to reflect amount has been discharged and no money owed. They took tax relief by issuing the 1099, but they are still trying to collect the debt. I've contacted the credit repositories (under FCRA guidelines) with proof of the 1099, yet they still refuse to update the credit reporting How can I get this resolved? BofA is the MOST frustrating bank to deal with, and are notorious for mis-reporting items and "slow playing" correcting financial issues. Please let me know if there's something I'm missing here. Thank you.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Credit repair,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: 1. Get a copy of your credit report from the "Big 3": Experian, TransUnion, Equifax. 2. Dispute every negative item. 3. Demand verification of each negative item. 4. Submit a "consumer statement" giving "your side of the story". 5. Be persistent. 6. Don't hire a credit repair service because you can do the same thing they do for free. 7. Hire a lawyer to send BoA a certified letter threatening suit if they don't report correct info.

Yes, Bank of America does this often. Your argument is that although you owed the $30k, when they issued the 1099 you potentially incurred a taxable event, so they should be "estopped" from arguing that you still owe the money. This argument has worked many times in court when BOA has sued for collection of the debt across the country. I recommend that you contact an attorney in your state who is a specialist in contract law and help you with this issue.

A 1099 is a discharge of debt. BoA cannot continue to collect on it, though it CAN report it as a discharge (nonBK). There's a subtle difference here between FRCA and FDCPA which can interact in a situation like yours.

I deal with BoA often and yes, they are the most frustrating mostly because there's nobody to call or talk with. I've found that a letter, 30 days wait, a 2nd letter, 15 days wait, and a lawsuit usually fixes the problem. Once a creditor or debt collector wracks up enough violations it becomes a good case to take on.
You posted this question under "Bankruptcy" but never mentioned bankruptcy. Was that debt discharged via a bankruptcy? If not, how was it discharged?
